XXIV. Case in a felt the disgrace of his late defeat, and saw with anxiety the fame of his army mouldering away. He had been roughly handled at Placentia, his auxiliaries were cut to pieces, and in every skirmish, not worthy of a particular detail, the enemy had the advantage. He likewise knew by sure intelligence that Valens was advancing with his army, and that commander might reap the laurels of the war. To prevent a circumstance so humiliating, he resolved, with more cou- rage than judgment, to redeem his glory With this intent he marched to a village called Castorum(a), distant about twelve miles from Cremona. At that place, in a wood that overhangs the road, he station- ed the flower of his auxiliaries in ambus'- cade.
